items.content:
What are your thoughts when you look at this sculpture? Tell what you see.

Do you think it is beautiful or ugly?

Let us have a closer look: Read the title and think about it: The Destroyed City.
The sculpture is located in Rotterdam. The center of this city was destroyed by bombs in the Second World War. So the city had no center anymore, the heart of the city was struck. How did the sculptor made this clear?

Pay attention to the facial expression. Does this fit to the subject (the bombing of the city)?

Let us take a further look: what kind of shapes did Zadkine use? Are they angular or round?
Do they express softness or power? Why would Zadkine have chosen these shapes?

Think about your first ideas about this sculpture. Do you still think this way or have you changed your mind about this sculpture?

What you just did is called analysing art.
Art analysis is important to understand art, why it is made, how it is made. You will discover a lot about a work of art by analyzing it. It will enrich your point of view!

To analyse means to look at something and find out what kind of elements it is made of.

In analyzing art your own opinion plays a role, but the work of art is the main subject. You discover what is represented and how it is made by the artist. You also try to find out what purpose the work of art has.

We look at things like: what materials are used? What colours and shapes are to be seen and what is the effect of all this?

The components of which a work of art is made of, are called: the elements of art.


In the first chapter you have discovered that art is made with a purpose. And you have seen that the works of art serve different purposes. In this chapter we will have a look at the different tools which are available to the artist and how the artist can to tell us his message.
Just like a carpenter uses his hammer, nails and wood to make a box, an artist uses visual resources to make a piece of art.

● The visual resources are:
-materials (see Ch.2)
-tools (see Ch.2)
-elements of art

● The five most important elements of art are:

-light
-colour
-space
-shape
-composition (arrangement).

[In America composition is not included in the elements of art. They use another kind of schedule in formal art analysis: elements of art (line, shape/form, space, colour, light, value, texture) + principles of art (balance, emphasis, contrast, unity, movement, pattern, rythm).]

Light

In regarding the element of light, you ask the next questions: what is the source of the light (a lamp, the sun…) and what is the effect of the light?
Does it cast hard edged or soft edged shadows or does it cause a certain atmosphere? Is it drawing your attention to something?


The Elevation Of The Cross, by Peter Paul Rubens in 1610

Take a look at the painting by Rubens. What do you see? We see Christ whom is taken off the cross by several people who slowly hold him, support him and let him go.

All people in the painting look at Christ. He is the center point of the representation. All attention is aimed at him. This is not only because he is at the center and because everybody is looking at him. There is another reason that causes your attention to be drawn to Christ. What is the cause?

The cause is the "spot light" Rubens has used to shine on Christ. The background of the painting is very dark. Here and there some light shines on an arm or a shoulder, but Christ is really totally illuminated.

The element of light has been deliberately used by Rubens.


Colour

Just like you can draw the attention to something with light, you can do this also with colour. Look at the image made by Rossetti. Because of the striking colour of the hair (amidst of all the green), our attention is drawn to it. This is intensified by the gaze of girl at us.


La Ghirlandata, by Dante Charles Gabriel Rossetti, 1873

You can create an ambience in a painting with colour. You can make a happy atmosphere by using different pure colours. But you will attain a total different ambience by using only dark and gloomy colours. Just compare these two paintings. [colourful - gloomy]

By Monet

By Picasso

When colours in a painting are similar to reality, a painting will look realistic.
You can also choose to use different colours compared to reality, in case you want to create a whole new world. That is one of the funny things of drawing. You are allowed to use your imagination.

Space


Still life with an angel, by Bart Schaap

In some paintings or drawings there is a suggestion of space. You can see what is nearby and what is further away. Or you can almost feel that a form is round and that it has got volume. You can see the plasticity. Have a look at the drawing of Bart Schaap. You can see the angel sitting in front of the round vase. It is obvious that the vase is round, that it has got volume.
That is because of the gradience which indicates the shadow on the vase.

Elements of arts are mostly used in a combination. In the two exemples above, light and shape are combined. In this case the effect of light and shadow causes spatial effects on the surface of an object, we are talking about plasticity.


Shape

Do the shapes look realistic or has the artist re-shaped them? Are they rounded or angular? What effect do they have? If the artist has used other shapes than realistic shapes, why did he do so? What is the artist aiming at? Recall the sculpture of Zadkine, The Destroyed City. Zadkine deliberately chose to use shapes that did not resemble reality.

Lian Su, the maker of the works below, chose realistic shapes for the drawing and and for the painting she chose shapes which are not realistic. In both works perfume-bottles are represented. On the painting the forms of the bottles are not recognizable, but they seem to melt together to one new big form.


Perfume bottles by Liam Su Splinters, by Liam Su


Composition/arrangement

When you are making a piece of art, you always have make a choice about WHERE to put WHAT. Will you put everything in a row or do you prefer everything to be mixed up? Will you put the most important in the center. What effect will this cause? Will everything have the same height or not?
When you are thinking about the position of every part of the painting, you are thinking about arrangement (or composition).

Look at the drawing and painting of Liam (Perfume Bottles). You will see that she chose for two totally different arrangements. On the drawing the bottles are placed next to the edge of the drawing, which causes them to be partially outside the drawing. This way it looks like we are close to the bottles. It looks like we are watching a casual scene. Things that stand there by chance, and we are watching those things.
On the painting you can see everything is arranged around the center. The deformed bottles are on one pile in the center and the glass pieces are arranged in a circle around them. The artwork is obviously arranged around the center.

Look at the image above. What can you tell about the composition?

Below you can see a scheme which is a summary of how we analyse art.

The boxes are separated in this scheme, but in fact all the parts are connected. To express an idea or a feeling, the artist uses the subject matter and the form.

Look at the image below. Find out the meaning and what subject he has used to express the meaning.

The Scream, by Munch
